extracted_information: Loading indicators are visual cues that inform users about the status of a process or operation, such as loading data, processing a request, or uploading a file. They enhance user experience by providing feedback and managing expectations. Ensuring accessibility is crucial for all users, including those with disabilities, to perceive and understand the conveyed information. Inaccessible indicators can lead to poor user experience and exclusion. The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG 2.1) emphasize clear and consistent indication of the loading process.

loading_indicator_types.description: Displays a specific percentage or progress of the task.
Displays a continuous animation without a specific percentage or progress.

wcag_2_1_guidelines.animation_motion_sensitivity: Avoid animations that flash or blink more than three times per second.

items: Color Contrast and Visual Design: Use a color scheme with sufficient contrast (e.g., WCAG 2.1 minimums). Avoid colors too similar to background. Ensure visibility in different lighting and devices.

Animation and Motion Sensitivity: Provide options to pause or disable animations. Use smooth animations that do not flash or blink excessively. Ensure animation is not distracting or disorienting. Avoid animations that flash or blink more than three times per second.
Screen Reader Compatibility and ARIA Attributes: Use ARIA attributes to describe purpose and status. Provide alternative text. Ensure screen reader announcement on appearance or state change.
Providing Alternative Text: Use `aria-label`, visually hidden text, or `title` attribute for description.
Using Semantic HTML: Utilize appropriate HTML elements like `<progress>` for progressbars or `<div>` for alerts/status messages.

Testing Loading Indicators for Accessibility: Test with screen readers (e.g., JAWS, VoiceOver), keyboard navigation, other assistive technologies, and automated accessibility tools (e.g., WAVE, Lighthouse).
